awd_titl_txt: Modern Approaches for the Analysis of Social Media Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will develop statistical methods for the analysis of high-resolution data arising from social media applications. Technological growth has made possible the accumulation of data from social media platforms at unprecedented speed and volume. However, current methods for analyzing these data either lack interpretability, are computationally intense, or require a rigid data regimen. This project will use a flexible modeling framework to extract relevant information on a user's behavior. Although the project primarily will focus on Twitter data, the methods to be developed will be applicable to other social media data, such as Facebook, Instagram, Reddit, or TikTok, or any form of digital interaction. The results of this research will help managers, policymakers, and stakeholders better understand the types of actors they are interacting with on social media. The methods and code created by this project will be made publicly available. The investigators will mentor undergraduate and graduate students and interact with K12 students who are interested in using valid statistical approaches to solve problems arising in online social media.

This research project will develop statistical methods for binary and categorical functional data structures. The standard analysis of functional data relies fundamentally on the assumption that the intrinsic functions are continuous over the compact interval. The complexity of social media data, however, requires different assumptions. A Twitter user's posting pattern can be defined as a time series of some feature of the posting activity. The user's data then can be viewed as a binary-valued or categorical-valued random function defined over a time domain and observed at a fine grid point. The project will develop classification methods for non-continuous functional data, propose computationally efficient estimation algorithms, and study their theoretical properties. The methods to be developed will be extended to adapt to multiple binary-valued or categorical-valued curves per subject, acquired in a longitudinal design, as well as to account for additional covariate information. Regression models with categorical-valued functional covariates and their associated significance tests also will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Advancements in technology have enabled the rapid and large-scale collection of data from social media platforms. Existing methods for analyzing this data often struggle with being either difficult to interpret, computationally demanding, or inflexible in their data requirements. Functional data analysis (FDA) provides a flexible yet interpretable framework for modeling and extracting key features of a user's posting behavior on social media, based on the timing, relevant features of their posts during some specified time interval. This project focused on developing FDA-based methodologies to extract user-specific signals based on their posting behavior on social media platforms. The objectives of this award included 1) developing methods for the classification and clustering of binary (0-1 valued) functional data; ii) extending these methods to repeated 0-1 valued functional data while accounting for additional covariates; and iii) developing significance tests when the covariates are categorical functional data. Throughout the course of the project, we developed innovative statistical methods for modeling, prediction, classification, clustering, and hypothesis testing for binary and categorical functional data. The methods were motivated by an applied to various social media data. Below we summarize our key contributions. 

First, we introduced a flexible framework and computationally efficient methodology for classification and clustering of binary or categorical valued functional data. The proposed methods assume that for each such functional data object, there is a latent smooth (univariate or multivariate) process that completely characterize the observed data, and that given the full latent smooth process, the observations are independent. The techniques are applied to social media study where, in addition to the classification or clustering of social media agents with high accuracy, it allows to gain insights into the posting behavior of the various groups/clusters. The methods have been implemented in R packages available on GitHub and are either published in Computational Statistics and Data Analysis or currently under journal review. 

Second, we extended the framework to handle repeated observations of binary-valued functional data for each user and developed computationally efficient methods that extract the user-specific latent signal. These methods inspired by and applied to Twitter data from accounts monitored over several consecutive days and enabled to characterize the accounts’ daily posting behavior and classify them with high accuracy. The work contributed to a PhD thesis and has resulted in a couple of manuscripts that are currently under journal review. 

Third, the we developed test of hypotheses for logistic regression models with categorical-valued functional covariates to formally examine the impact of specific categories on class membership. We proposed a restricted likelihood ratio test, developed its null asymptotic distribution, and presented a computationally efficient approach to calculate the p-value. This technique was motivated by and applied to social media data from X (formerly Twitter) to examine how public statements made by Starbucks and McDonald's regarding the Israel-Hamas conflict influenced customer opinions. Specifically, we described the customers’ opinion through the sentiment of their tweets (positive, neutral, or negative) over a recent period of time and assessed whether a positive sentiment played a significant role in shifting customer opinions toward the company in response to its stance on the conflict. This work contributed to another PhD thesis and led to a manuscript which will be shortly submitted for journal publication. 

This award provided the PIs with opportunities to integrate the proposed research into educational activities that have had a meaningful impact on society at multiple levels. It enabled the PIs to train high school students in working with and analyzing social media data, fostering early interest and competence in data analytics. The insights gained from this research have been instrumental in writing and securing two additional grants, and have formed the basis for the training of six undergraduate students. Additionally, software developed from this research has been made publicly available on GitHub for wider dissemination. Our findings have been showcased at many conferences in statistics and social media-related, contributing to the professional development of attendees and influencing the discussions within the field. The results of this research are also being disseminated through publications in major journals ensuring ongoing visibility and impact.
